Judge Michael A. Ponsor: MEMORANDUM AND ORDER entered, as follows: The court finds that Defendants' policy of permitting male guards to videotape strip searches, even if no viewing occurred, in non-emergency situations, violated the class members' constitutional rights and that no legitimate, penological interest justified it. Defendants' Motion for Summary Judgment (Dkt. No. 156) is hereby DENIED, and Plaintiffs' Motion for Summary Judgment (Dkt. No. 171) is hereby ALLOWED on the issue of liability. By September 9, 2014, Plaintiff shall submit a proposed schedule to address the questions of potential equitable relief and monetary damages. If Plaintiff's proposal is not assented to, Defendants may submit their counter-proposal by September 23, 2014. It is So Ordered. See the attached memorandum and order for full decision. (Kaplan, Jennifer) (Entered: 08/26/2014)

ORDER of USCA as to 225 Notice of Appeal filed by Michael J. Ashe, Patricia Murphy.ORDER entered by Juan R. Torruella, Appellate Judge: On March 3, 2015, the parties filed a Joint Motion for a Preliminary Fairness Hearing in the district court. On March 5, 2015, the district court granted the motion and scheduled a preliminary fairness hearing for April 9, 2015. On March 16, the parties filed a joint motion to remand this case to the district court for the purpose of holding preliminary and final settlement fairness hearings. We regard the district court's intention to schedule a fairness hearing as a sufficient statement that it believes that the parties' Joint Motion for a Preliminary Fairness Hearing "raises a substantial issue." Fed. R. Civ. P. 62.1(a)(3); see also Fed. R. App. P. 12.1(b). In view of the district court's March 5, 2015, order embodying that view, the case is remanded to the district court for proceedings consistent with that order. Jurisdiction is retained. Once the district court concludes its proceedings, then the parties should proceed in accordance with Fed. R. App. P. 42(b) or propose some other disposition. Appellants shall file a status report every 60 days. (Paine, Matthew) (Entered: 04/02/2015)

Magistrate Judge Kenneth P. Neiman: ELECTRONIC ORDER entered granting in part and denying in part 60 the Massachusetts Department of Correction ("MDOC")'s Motion to Intervene and Motion to Quash or Modify Subpoena of Plaintiffs. As an initial matter, the requests for intervention and to entirely quash the subpoena are DENIED. The request for Modification of the subpoena, however, is GRANTED, but in part only, as follows. First, this order shall apply to all three state correctional institutions which are the subject of the subpoena. Second, Plaintiffs and MDOC shall forthwith enter into a Protective Order substantially if not entirely similar to the protective order which applies to Plaintiffs and Defendants. Third, by May 9, 2013, and subject to the further provisos below, MDOC shall produce the public policies and procedures to Plaintiffs. Fourth, by May 16, 2013, MDOC shall produce to Plaintiffs the private policies, i.e., staff access only policies, and the post orders to Plaintiffs, subject to the further provisos below. Fifth, notwithstanding the protective order, MDOC may redact from the private policies and post orders such material as falls entirely outside the subject matter of Schedule A of the subpoena, on the further condition, however, that the general subject matter of the redacted portions shall be described to Plaintiffs by MDOC; Plaintiffs are free to challenge those redactions at a later date.. Sixth, MDOC need only produce current policies and procedures (whether public or private) and post orders of an institution if those policies, procedures and/or post orders, as applicable, are accompanied by an affidavit which indicates that they have not materially changed since September of 2008. So ordered. (Neiman, Kenneth) (Entered: 05/02/2013)

Magistrate Judge Kenneth P. Neiman: ELECTRONIC ORDER entered denying 87 Defendants' Motion for Protective Order. First, the court sees no reason to preclude Plaintiffs from taking video depositions in accord with Fed.R.Civ.P. 30(b)(3). Second, the court has not been persuaded that a protective order of the sort requested is necessary given Plaintiffs' representations that they have no present intention to disseminate the videos publicly. That said, should Plaintiffs change their mind, they are cautioned "that the decision to publicize any recording, on the internet or otherwise, may be regarded as an effort to taint the jury pool in advance of trial." Capitol Records v. Alaujan, 2009 WL 5873130 *2 (D.Mass. June 16, 2009). That caution should be heeded here in particular given Plaintiffs' previous steps to publicize this case. So ordered. (Neiman, Kenneth) (Entered: 05/30/2013)

Magistrate Judge Kenneth P. Neiman: ELECTRONIC ORDER entered denying 104 Defendants' Motion to Amend Answer so as to add an affirmative defense regarding the named plaintiff's and/or members of the class's failure to exhaust their administrative remedies. as assertedly required by 42 U.S.C. section 1997e(a), the Prison Litigation Reform Act ("PLRA"). Even putting aside Plaintiffs' argument that the PLRA does not apply here (which argument has merit), the court finds that Defendants' motion -- which comes nearly two years after Defendants filed their original answer to the complaint, almost eighteen months after the commencement of discovery, and a matter of weeks before the expiration of fact discovery on liability (a deadline extended at Defendants' request without any mention by them of this affirmative defense)-- was unduly delayed and will cause undue prejudice to Plaintiffs. In this regard, Defendants give no persuasive reason for delaying the invocation of such an affirmative defense, one with which they should have been familiar since the commencement of this action, and fail to fully appreciate the extensive additional discovery which would have to be undertaken were the motion allowed. At best, Defendants argue that, because of the relatively recent certification of the class, this defense is "only now applicable to the members of the class." As Plaintiffs assert, this argument has no weight; the complaint was filed as a class action and contained class allegations, affirmative defenses were "applicable" to class members all along, and Defendants understood this when they filed their answer and included other affirmative defenses explicitly directed toward the "alleged class." (Neiman, Kenneth) (Entered: 09/16/2013)

Magistrate Judge Kenneth P. Neiman: ELECTRONIC ORDER entered granting 117 Plaintiffs' Motion to Compel. Although Defendants did not waive their right to object to the disclosure, the court concludes, after reviewing the seven emails in question, that the documents are not protected by either an attorney-client privilege or the work-product doctrine and, further, are not evidence related to an expert under Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(b)(4)(D). Mr. Milosovich was identified by Defendants as a fact witness, was deposed in that capacity without objection, and the emails are potentially relevant to that testimony, even though Defendants now assert that the emails are of little import to this case. (See Defendants' Opposition (Document No. 134) at page 1.) The documents will remain under seal by the court (as discovery materials) but shall be forthwith provided to Plaintiffs by Defendants. So ordered. (Neiman, Kenneth) (Entered: 12/11/2013)

Magistrate Judge Kenneth P. Neiman: ELECTRONIC ORDER entered granting in part and denying in part 120 Plaintiffs' Motion to Strike Witnesses and Documents Identified in Disclosures Made After the Close of Discovery, as follows. The motion is ALLOWED without objection with regard to witness DeCou. The motion is also ALLOWED with regard to the following witnesses: Bernardi-Agnes, Connor, Harriman, Lyman, Pfister and Pratt. In so ruling, the court finds first that Defendants' justification for the late disclosure is unconvincing; all of these individuals were known to Defendants for quite some time as having information with regard to this action but nonetheless were not disclosed. Second, the fact that some of their names may have appeared in the thousands of pages of documents does not amount to appropriate disclosures; indeed, Defendants themselves indicate that several of these witnesses' names may have appeared only once or twice, others not at all, and yet others a bit more often but with no explanation of the context of those occasions. (See Opposition (Document No. 135) at pages 3 through 5.) Third, Defendants' assertion that the broad-based disclosures in their October 5, 2012 Supplemental Automatic Disclosures would suffice is particularly unpersuasive; as Plaintiffs argue, this approach to disclosure would not only violate Rule 26(a)(1) but swallow it whole. Fourth, Defendants' argument to the contrary, these late disclosures would in fact adversely affect not only Plaintiffs' ability to complete appropriate discovery but would inappropriately extend the court's management of this litigation. And fifth, Defendants' argument that most of these witnesses "are likely of only tangential import to this case" (Defendants' Opposition at page 1) actually mitigates against, not for, their being included as witnesses, to wit, there is apparently less need for the precluded evidence than Defendants might otherwise argue. The motion, however, is DENIED with regard to witnesses Blair, Laurens, Morales, but only in their capacities as former inmates at the facility. Given some of Plaintiffs' deposition testimony, Defendants should have the opportunity to present these three individuals as witnesses, subject to Defendants paying the costs of any depositions which Plaintiffs may wish to take of them. The motion is also DENIED with respect to certain HCCC Policies and Procedures, it appearing to the court that these documents are either the same as or closely related to documents previously produced by Defendants. In contrast, the motion is ALLOWED with regard to audits by the American Correctional Association and the Department of Correction prior to 2008, the court concluding that these documents ought to have been revealed earlier insofar as they may have influenced the procedures utilized by Defendants and at issue in this case. In so ruling, the court acknowledges that Plaintiffs have acceded to yet other late disclosures which are not at issue. So ordered. (Neiman, Kenneth) (Entered: 12/09/2013)

Magistrate Judge Kenneth P. Neiman: ELECTRONIC ORDER entered granting in part 25 Plaintiffs' Second Motion to Compel, as follows. Defendants shall fully respond to Request No. 8 with regard to all incident reports requested to the extent not yet produced. With regard to Request No 9, Defendants shall provide, in addition to videos already produced, access to all videos (in which a female corrections officer held the video camera) for every third month beginning September of 2008 through the relevant three-and-one-half tear time period. In so ruling, the court finds that the scope of discovery is broader than what Defendants profess and that, for the various reasons set forth in Plaintiffs' motion, the discovery is potentially relevant to the claims of the putative class. The court also concludes that any privacy interests of the videotaped inmates would be more than adequately protected by the existing protective order. In limiting the discovery to every third month, however, the court recognizes the burdens placed on Defendants while ensuring that an appropriate sample of potential evidence is produced. Defendants shall produce the discovery no later than October 26, 2012. So ordered. (Neiman, Kenneth) (Entered: 10/04/2012)

case_data.name: Baggett v. Ashe
case_data.plaintiff_description: All women strip searched at the Western Massachusetts Regional Womenโs Correctional Center while a male officer videotaped the strip search, since September 15, 2008.
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
case_data.summary:
On September 15, 2011, former prisoners at the Western Massachusetts Regional Women's Correctional Center ("WCC") filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 against the Hampden County Sheriff's Department. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel, sought money damages, alleging that the Sheriff's Department violated their Fourth Amendment rights by allowing male officers to be present for and videotape non-emergency strip searches.

Following discovery and arguments on the specifics of the Sheriff Department's policies with regards to non-emergency strip searches, on May 23, 2013 the District Court (Judge Michael A. Ponsor) granted plaintiffs' motion for class certification. The class consisted of 178 current and former WCC inmates who were videotaped by male correctional officers during strip searches. The Sheriff's Department appealed, but the First Circuit denied hearing the appeal.

On August 26, 2014, Judge Ponsor granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, finding that the mere presence of male corrections officer during non-emergency strip searches violated plaintiffs' Fourth Amendment rights. Further proceedings were deemed necessary to determine the issue of liability and potential monetary and equitable relief. The Sheriff's Department appealed the order to the First Circuit. While that ruling was pending on appeal, the court stayed further proceedings on Oct. 3, 2014.

Meanwhile, the parties reached a settlement in March 2015: the state (not the county) agreed to pay $675,000. $475,000 was allocated to the plaintiffs' attorneys for fees and $22,000 for costs; $20,000 to the lead plaintiff; $2,000 each to four plaintiffs who were deposed, and the remaining class members were set to receive at least $850, and more depending on the claiming rate. In addition, defendants agreed to change their policy to prohibit male officers from holding the video camera during strip searches except in exigent circumstances, as defined in the Prison Rape Elimination Act regulation, which defined "exigent circumstances" to be "any set of temporary and unforeseen circumstances that require immediate action in order to combat a threat to the security or institutional order of a facility." PREA Standards ยง 115.5. The defendants were to provide plaintiffs with statistics, a copy of the video of the full movie and strip search and any reports or materials documenting the need for the male videotaping up until June 30, 2016.

On April 2, 2015, the First Circuit remanded the case back to the district court in response to the parties' joint motion requesting the remand for purposes of holding a settlement fairness hearing.

A preliminary fairness hearing was held on April 9, 2015, and Judge Ponsor agreed to proceed to a final fairness hearing. On September 10, 2015 the court found the settlement fair and reasonable, and approved it; it also granted $475,000 in attorneys' fees and $22,000 in costs pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1988. The First Circuit terminated the appeal on Sept. 16, 2015 in response to the parties voluntarily dismissing the appeal.

The case is now closed.
case_data.summary_short: On September 15, 2011, former inmates at a Massachusetts Correctional Center filed a class action against Hampden County Sheriff's Department on allegations that the Department violated their Fourth Amendment rights by allowing male officers to be present for non-emergency strip searches. Judge Ponsor approved a settlement agreement in 2015.

05/30/2013 93  Magistrate Judge Kenneth P. Neiman: ELECTRONIC ORDER entered denying 87
Defendants' Motion for Protective Order. First, the court sees no reason to preclude
Plaintiffs from taking video depositions in accord with Fed.R.Civ.P. 30(b)(3). Second,
the court has not been persuaded that a protective order of the sort requested is
necessary given Plaintiffs' representations that they have no present intention to
disseminate the videos publicly. That said, should Plaintiffs change their mind, they
are cautioned "that the decision to publicize any recording, on the internet or
otherwise, may be regarded as an effort to taint the jury pool in advance of trial."
Capitol Records v. Alaujan, 2009 WL 5873130 *2 (D.Mass. June 16, 2009). That
caution should be heeded here in particular given Plaintiffs' previous steps to publicize

09/16/2013 108  Magistrate Judge Kenneth P. Neiman: ELECTRONIC ORDER entered denying 104
Defendants' Motion to Amend Answer so as to add an affirmative defense regarding
the named plaintiff's and/or members of the class's failure to exhaust their
administrative remedies. as assertedly required by 42 U.S.C. section 1997e(a), the
Prison Litigation Reform Act ("PLRA"). Even putting aside Plaintiffs' argument that
the PLRA does not apply here (which argument has merit), the court finds that
Defendants' motion โโ which comes nearly two years after Defendants filed their
original answer to the complaint, almost eighteen months after the commencement of
discovery, and a matter of weeks before the expiration of fact discovery on liability (a

Case: 3:11-cv-30223   As of: 01/18/2018 06:56 PM EST   12 of 23
deadline extended at Defendants' request without any mention by them of this
affirmative defense)โโ was unduly delayed and will cause undue prejudice to
Plaintiffs. In this regard, Defendants give no persuasive reason for delaying the
invocation of such an affirmative defense, one with which they should have been
familiar since the commencement of this action, and fail to fully appreciate the
extensive additional discovery which would have to be undertaken were the motion
allowed. At best, Defendants argue that, because of the relatively recent certification of
the class, this defense is "only now applicable to the members of the class." As
Plaintiffs assert, this argument has no weight; the complaint was filed as a class action
and contained class allegations, affirmative defenses were "applicable" to class
members all along, and Defendants understood this when they filed their answer and
included other affirmative defenses explicitly directed toward the "alleged class."
(Neiman, Kenneth) (Entered: 09/16/2013)

12/09/2013 147  Magistrate Judge Kenneth P. Neiman: ELECTRONIC ORDER entered granting in
part and denying in part 120 Plaintiffs' Motion to Strike Witnesses and Documents
Identified in Disclosures Made After the Close of Discovery, as follows. The motion is
ALLOWED without objection with regard to witness DeCou. The motion is also
ALLOWED with regard to the following witnesses: BernardiโAgnes, Connor,
Harriman, Lyman, Pfister and Pratt. In so ruling, the court finds first that Defendants'
justification for the late disclosure is unconvincing; all of these individuals were
known to Defendants for quite some time as having information with regard to this
action but nonetheless were not disclosed. Second, the fact that some of their names
may have appeared in the thousands of pages of documents does not amount to
appropriate disclosures; indeed, Defendants themselves indicate that several of these
witnesses' names may have appeared only once or twice, others not at all, and yet
others a bit more often but with no explanation of the context of those occasions. (See
Opposition (Document No. 135) at pages 3 through 5.) Third, Defendants' assertion
that the broadโbased disclosures in their October 5, 2012 Supplemental Automatic

Case: 3:11-cv-30223   As of: 01/18/2018 06:56 PM EST   15 of 23
Disclosures would suffice is particularly unpersuasive; as Plaintiffs argue, this
approach to disclosure would not only violate Rule 26(a)(1) but swallow it whole.
Fourth, Defendants' argument to the contrary, these late disclosures would in fact
adversely affect not only Plaintiffs' ability to complete appropriate discovery but
would inappropriately extend the court's management of this litigation. And fifth,
Defendants' argument that most of these witnesses "are likely of only tangential import
to this case" (Defendants' Opposition at page 1) actually mitigates against, not for,
their being included as witnesses, to wit, there is apparently less need for the precluded
evidence than Defendants might otherwise argue. The motion, however, is DENIED
with regard to witnesses Blair, Laurens, Morales, but only in their capacities as former
inmates at the facility. Given some of Plaintiffs' deposition testimony, Defendants
should have the opportunity to present these three individuals as witnesses, subject to
Defendants paying the costs of any depositions which Plaintiffs may wish to take of
them. The motion is also DENIED with respect to certain HCCC Policies and
Procedures, it appearing to the court that these documents are either the same as or
closely related to documents previously produced by Defendants. In contrast, the
motion is ALLOWED with regard to audits by the American Correctional Association
and the Department of Correction prior to 2008, the court concluding that these
documents ought to have been revealed earlier insofar as they may have influenced the
procedures utilized by Defendants and at issue in this case. In so ruling, the court
acknowledges that Plaintiffs have acceded to yet other late disclosures which are not at
issue. So ordered. (Neiman, Kenneth) (Entered: 12/09/2013)
12/11/2013 148  Magistrate Judge Kenneth P. Neiman: ELECTRONIC ORDER entered granting 117
Plaintiffs' Motion to Compel. Although Defendants did not waive their right to object
to the disclosure, the court concludes, after reviewing the seven emails in question,
that the documents are not protected by either an attorneyโclient privilege or the
workโproduct doctrine and, further, are not evidence related to an expert under Fed. R.
Civ. P. 26(b)(4)(D). Mr. Milosovich was identified by Defendants as a fact witness,
was deposed in that capacity without objection, and the emails are potentially relevant
to that testimony, even though Defendants now assert that the emails are of little
import to this case. (See Defendants' Opposition (Document No. 134) at page 1.) The
documents will remain under seal by the court (as discovery materials) but shall be
forthwith provided to Plaintiffs by Defendants. So ordered. (Neiman, Kenneth)

searches, even if no viewing occurred, in nonโemergency situations, violated the class
members' constitutional rights and that no legitimate, penological interest justified it.
Defendants' Motion for Summary Judgment (Dkt. No. 156) is hereby DENIED, and
Plaintiffs' Motion for Summary Judgment (Dkt. No. 171) is hereby ALLOWED on the
issue of liability. By September 9, 2014, Plaintiff shall submit a proposed schedule to
address the questions of potential equitable relief and monetary damages. If Plaintiff's
proposal is not assented to, Defendants may submit their counterโproposal by
September 23, 2014. It is So Ordered. See the attached memorandum and order for full
decision. (Kaplan, Jennifer) (Entered: 08/26/2014)

ORDER entered by Juan R. Torruella, Appellate Judge: On March 3, 2015, the parties
filed a Joint Motion for a Preliminary Fairness Hearing in the district court. On March
5, 2015, the district court granted the motion and scheduled a preliminary fairness
hearing for April 9, 2015. On March 16, the parties filed a joint motion to remand this
case to the district court for the purpose of holding preliminary and final settlement
fairness hearings. We regard the district court's intention to schedule a fairness hearing
as a sufficient statement that it believes that the parties' Joint Motion for a Preliminary
Fairness Hearing "raises a substantial issue." Fed. R. Civ. P. 62.1(a)(3); see also Fed.
R. App. P. 12.1(b). In view of the district court's March 5, 2015, order embodying that
view, the case is remanded to the district court for proceedings consistent with that
order. Jurisdiction is retained. Once the district court concludes its proceedings, then
the parties should proceed in accordance with Fed. R. App. P. 42(b) or propose some
other disposition. Appellants shall file a status report every 60 days.

documents.text:
Case 3:11-cv-30223-MAP   Document 242-1   Filed 03/31/15   Page 1 of 20
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE DISTRICT OF MASSACHUSETTS 
__________________________________________ 
) 
DEBRA BAGGETT, et al.,  ) 
Plaintiffs,        ) 
)  Civil Action No. 11-30223-MAP 
v.        ) 
) 
MICHAEL J. ASHE, JR., et al., and  ) 
Defendants        ) 
__________________________________________) 
 
SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT 
 
I.   SUMMARY 
1.   The parties to this action, class representative Debra Baggett, individually and on 
behalf of the Class (โPlaintiffsโ), and Michael J. Ashe, Jr., and Patricia Murphy, in their individual 
capacities (โDefendantsโ), by counsel, have entered into this Settlement Agreement, which they 
submit to the Court for approval. The Agreement requires Defendants to change their policy to 
prohibit male correctional officers from holding the camera during the strip searches of female 
inmates  except  in  exigent  circumstances.  The  Agreement  provides  that  Defendants  will  settle 
Plaintiffsโ claims for $675,000, to be allocated as follows, subject to the approval of the Court: Class 
Members will receive a total of $178,000 (the โClass Member Poolโ), which will be divided equally 
among participating class members after payment of a $20,000 bonus to the class representative and 
$2,000 bonuses to each of the four class members who had their depositions taken. Under this 
Agreement, participating class members will receive one payment each no matter how many times 
they were videotaped by a male officer during the class period. Plaintiffsโ counsel will receive a total 
of $497,000, of which $475,000 represents attorneyโs fees and $22,000 represents costs.  This is a

II.   BACKGROUND 
2.  Class representative Debra Baggett is a former  inmate at the Western Massachusetts 
Regional Womenโs Correctional Center (โWCCโ) in Chicopee, Massachusetts. The WCC is part of 
the Hampden County Sheriffโs Department (โHCSDโ).  
3.  Defendant Michael J. Ashe, Jr., is the Sheriff of Hampden County. 
4.  Defendant Patricia Murphy is the Assistant Superintendent in charge of the WCC. 
5.  Plaintiff filed this class action lawsuit for damages on September 15, 2011, alleging, 
inter alia, that Defendantsโ policy permitting male correctional officers at the WCC to videotape 
female  inmates being strip searched in non-emergency situations violated the Fourth Amendment. 
6.  On May 23, 2013, the Court certified this case as a class action pursuant to Rule 
23(b)(3) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. The class is defined as โAll women strip searched 
at  the  Western  Massachusetts  Regional  Womenโs  Correctional  Center  while  a  male  officer 
videotaped the strip search, since September 15, 2008.โ The parties have identified 176 women who 
meet this definition (โClass Membersโ). Class membership was determined by reviewing incident 
reports about moves to the Segregation Unit at the WCC and videotapes of these moves and 
attendant strip searches.  
7.  By Memorandum and Order dated August 26, 2014, the Court granted Plaintiffsโ 
Motion  for  Summary  Judgment.  The  Court  ruled  that  Defendantsโ  policy  permitting  male 
correctional officers to videotape female inmates during strip searches in non-emergency situations 
violated Class Membersโ constitutional rights, and that Defendants were liable to class members for 
these violations. 
8.  Defendants deny any wrongdoing or unlawful conduct on their own part or on the 
part of their employees or staff. Defendants deny that any male officers ever watched any portion of 
the strip search of a female inmate. They reassert that any cross-gender viewing was expressly 
forbidden by policy, procedure, and training, that there was a Supervisor present at every strip search 
2

to ensure compliance with policy, procedure, and training, and that neither Defendants nor their 
staff  ever  received  a  written  grievance  about  the  challenged  practice.  Plaintiffs  dispute  these 
assertions. On September 17, 2014, Defendants filed a notice of appeal of the Courtโs decision to 
the First Circuit Court of Appeals.  
9.  The parties reached this Agreement before any briefs were filed in the First Circuit. 
10.  The  parties  reached  this  Agreement  after  engaging  in  armโs-length  settlement 
negotiations, including a mediation session and multiple follow-up discussions with the Honorable 
Patrick King, Settlement Counsel at the First Circuit Court of Appeals. Following an in-person 
session with Judge King on November 4, 2014, the parties continued negotiations for more than a 
month  via  telephone  and  email  with  Judge  King  serving  as  an  intermediary.  Judge  King 
recommended the Total Settlement Amount to the parties and he endorsed the manner in which 
this amount is divided among Class Members, the named Plaintiff, the Class Member deponents, 
and attorneyโs fees and costs. 
11.  Plaintiffsโ counsel conducted a thorough examination and investigation of the facts 
and law relating to this litigation. The parties engaged in comprehensive discovery for almost two 
years. Discovery included 23 depositions including those of the named Plaintiff and the Defendants; 
Class Members and other former WCC  inmates who are not class members; numerous Hampden 
County Sheriffโs Department correctional officers, supervisors, and administrators; and an outside 
consultant to the Sheriffโs Department. The parties engaged in extensive document discovery, 
including the production by Defendants of more than 15,000 pages of documents. Pursuant to 
subpoena, nonparties the Massachusetts Department of Correction (โDOCโ) and the Middlesex 
County Sheriffโs Department produced more than 1,000 pages in total. Defendants produced more 
than 800 videos of moves to Segregation and accompanying strip searches, including 274 videos of 
moves and strip searches in which a male correctional officer held the video camera during the strip 
search. Plaintiffs and Defendants both served expert reports from correctional professionals.

18.   All parties understand that this agreement will require the approval of the Court. All

  19.   Defendants will amend the WCC policy on inmate movement to prohibit male 
officers from holding the video camera during strip searches except in exigent circumstances. The 
restriction on male officersโ videotaping strip searches shall be the same restriction as applies in 
Defendantsโ policies to male officersโ conducting strip searches. The restriction in both cases shall 
mirror the restriction on cross-gender strip searches and cross-gender visual body cavity searches in 
the final standards of the Prison Rape Elimination Act (โPREAโ), which prohibit such searches 
except in exigent circumstances. PREA Standards ยง 115.15. Defendantsโ policies shall adopt the 
PREA standardsโ definition of โexigent circumstances,โ which are โany set of temporary and 
unforeseen circumstances that require immediate action in order to combat a threat to the security 
or institutional order of a facility.โ PREA Standards ยง 115.5.  Within thirty (30) days of the Courtโs 
granting preliminary approval of the settlement, Defendants shall provide Plaintiffsโ counsel with an 
unsigned final draft of all amended policy documents containing the changes required under this 
Agreement. Defendants shall make the amended policies effective no later than thirty (30) days after 
the Courtโs final approval of the settlement, by which time they shall provide Plaintiffsโ counsel with 
copies of the signed, effective version of all amended policy documents.   
  20.  The above restrictions shall be included in the following places in Defendantsโ 
written policies and procedures (โP&Pโsโ).

currently requiring female officers to videotape strip searches โunless impracticable to do

53.   The Commonwealth will be responsible for all tax withholding and reporting as 
required by law.  Participating Class Members are responsible for payment of any additional taxes 
and other withholdings for which they are legally responsible that may become due on settlement 
proceeds, and hold Defendants, and their counsel harmless from any and all claims for said taxes 
and withholdings thereon.  
54.  Each Participating Class Memberโs check will be made payable only in her name or 
in the name of a deceased Class Memberโs estate, provided the duly appointed estate representative 
has complied with ยถ 61 and completed a W-9 Form, and subject to the provisions of Paragraph 52. 
If the Class Memberโs address is listed on the Distribution List as โClass Member c/o [another 
individual]โ, the Commonwealth shall ensure that the Class Memberโs check is not made payable to 
the โClass Member c/o [such individual].โ The check will contain a memo or other indication that it 
is payment for the โHampden County class action settlement,โ to help Class Members identify the 
purpose of the check. The check will be mailed to the Participating Class Member at the legal 
address indicated on the Claim Form or as updated as provided in Paragraph 51, above. The 
Commonwealth shall not make changes to the addresses or other information on the Distribution 
16 
 

Case 3:11-cv-30223-MAP   Document 242-1   Filed 03/31/15   Page 17 of 20
List  without  prior  approval  from  Plaintiffsโ  counsel.  If  any  Class  Member  contacts  the 
Commonwealth with new contact information, the Commonwealth will provide this information to 
LOHF and tell the Class Member to contact LOHF.  
55.  If a Participating Class Member is confined in a prison, hospital, or other institution 
and has provided the address of such institution for payment, the settlement check will be sent to 
that address unless the Participating Class Member makes other acceptable arrangements in writing 
with LOHF. 
VIII.   POST-DISTRIBUTION ADMINISTRATION 
  56.   The Commonwealth will prepare all 1099s, and any other tax forms relating to the 
settlement that are required by law, for all Participating Class Members during the next regular tax-
form processing period following the distribution. 
57.  Within 60 days of mailing settlement checks to Class Members, the Commonwealth 
will  provide  to  LOHF  a  settlement  distribution  report  accounting  for  the  distribution  of  the 
Settlement Proceeds, including attorneyโs fees and expenses. The report shall contain the following 
information for each Participating Class Member: full name; taxpayer identification number; vendor 
customer code; check number; check issue date; check clear date; amount of payment; amount of 
interception by the Commonwealth, if any; and address to which the check was sent. 
58.  One year after the original date of the first distribution, the Commonwealth will 
provide a final report accounting for the distribution of the Settlement Proceeds, upon written 
request, which shall include the information described in ยถ 57.  
  59.   Class Members will be informed in the Claim Form that all settlement checks must 
be cashed within sixty days.  
  60.   Checks not presented for payment within one year from the original date of issue 
will be subject to M.G.L. c. 29, ยง 32. 
17 
 

Case 3:11-cv-30223-MAP   Document 242-1   Filed 03/31/15   Page 18 of 20
IX.   DECEASED CLASS MEMBERS 
  61.   If a Class Member is deceased, an authorized representative may file a Settlement 
Claim Form on behalf of the estate. However, the representative must provide to LOHF 
documentation that an estate has been established in accordance with the law and that he or she is 
the duly appointed representative. 
X.   RELEASE AND DISMISSAL 
 
 
  62.   In consideration of payment of the Settlement Proceeds, and the Defendantsโ other 
undertakings hereunder, and for other good and sufficient consideration, the receipt and sufficiency 
of which is hereby acknowledged, Plaintiffs, including those Class Members who do not file claims, 
hereby remise, release, acquit, satisfy, and forever discharge Defendants Michael J. Ashe, Jr., and 
Patricia Murphy, in their individual and official capacities, the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and 
all of their present and former agents, servants, independent contractors, officers, officials, 
employees and insurers as well as each of their estates, heirs, executors, personal representatives, 
successors in interest, and assigns (the โReleased Partiesโ),  of and from any and all manner of 
action and actions, cause or causes of action, suits, debts, dues, claims, rights, compensation, 
attorneysโ fees, costs, expenses, compensation, damages and demands, including all known and 
unknown, foreseen and unforeseen, developed and undeveloped damages and the consequences 
thereof, and any and all claims of every kind, nature, and description whatsoever, in law (be it 
constitutional, statutory, or common law) or in equity, which Plaintiffs now have or ever had arising 
out of or in any way related to the allegations in the Complaint in the action entitled Baggett, et al. v. 
Ashe, et al., United States District Court Civil Action No. 11-30223-MAP (D. Mass.), including any 
claims related to any of the inmate moves and/or strip searches at issue in the above action. 
  63.  It is the express intent of the Plaintiffs to enter into and be bound by this full and 
final Settlement Agreement to settle and compromise all claims against the Defendants by the 
18 
 

Case 3:11-cv-30223-MAP   Document 242-1   Filed 03/31/15   Page 19 of 20
Plaintiffs.  Plaintiffs agree to the entry of a dismissal with prejudice of United States District Court 
Civil Action No. 11-30223-MAP (D. Mass.) upon Defendantsโ and the Commonwealthโs 
performance in full of the terms of this Settlement Agreement, and upon Plaintiffsโ receipt of the 
final distribution report as described in ยถ 58, except that Plaintiffs agree that any required statistical 
reporting set forth in Paragraph 21 above that is not yet required at the time that Defendants and 
the Commonwealth have performed all other terms of this Agreement will not delay the entry of 
dismissal with prejudice.   
  64.  The Plaintiffs agree and acknowledge that no promise, inducement, or agreement, 
not expressly contained in this agreement, has been made to them.  This Settlement Agreement  
supersedes any and all previous agreements or understandings, whether written or oral and contains 
the entire agreement by and among the Plaintiffs and the Released Parties with respect to the 
allegations in the Complaint in the action of Baggett, et al. v. Ashe, et al., United States District Court 
Civil Action No. 11-30223-MAP (D. Mass.), including any claims related to any of the inmate moves 
and/or strip searches at issue in the above action.   
  65.  It is the express intent of Defendants and of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts 
to be bound by this Settlement Agreement. 
XI.   COURT SUPERVISION 
66.  Until the aforesaid action has been dismissed pursuant to Paragraph 63 above, but 
not  thereafter,  the  Court  will  retain  jurisdiction  over  the  settlement  and  may  enter  orders  as 
appropriate to enforce it, to adjudicate the rights and responsibilities of the parties, and to effect fair 
and orderly administration. 
67.  Any deadlines, dates, or other details in this Settlement Agreement may be changed 
by the Court on a showing of good cause.  
 
19
